Louis Gordon Rylands (10 July 1862 - 20 December 1942), best known as L. Gordon Rylands was a British criminologist and writer.
Rylands was born in Warrington, Lancashire. His father was the politician Peter Rylands. He was educated at Charterhouse and University College London (B.A., B.Sc). After completing his studies, he was secretary of the family business, Rylands Brothers wire manufacturers from 1884 to 1887, then from 1897 to 1898 was science master at the Royal Grammar School, Newcastle upon Tyne. He worked as a private tutor from 1898 to 1924. At the time of his death he was assistant registrar of Grimes's Manchester Tutorial College. In 1887, he married Katherine Edwards; they had a daughter. Rylands was an uncle of the academic Dadie Rylands.Rylands authored the book Crime: Its Causes and Remedy (1889). Rylands was best known as an advocate of the Christ myth theory. He denied the historicity of Jesus.

response: Rylands married twice. He had three sons by his second wife Caroline Reynolds, whom he married in 1861. His eldest son, the author L. Gordon Rylands, published an edition of his letters."The Man of Philanthropy, Politics and Clogs". Warrington Museum & Art Gallery. A grandson was the academic Dadie Rylands.
